description: App crash after device rotation
fix: Crashes happened when the user rotates the device multiple times before the webview finishes it's request to github for the login page. This caused the UI to not update correctly.Fix: added config changes to AndroidManifest.xml in LoginWebViewActivity tag to prevent this activity from being recreated on orientation change and making multiple web calls.

description: Account selector UI that overlays on top of the root UI gets created multiple times, once with every orientation change rotation. Then, I have to tap on the desired account once for each instance, as they disappear one by one, and after the last one, app crashes:
fix: I can't reproduce this, but I know it's happened to me too a few times before. While the stacktrace is the same, I think this is a completely different issue than #549. Basically, our fragments stay alive beyond the activity lifecycle so that we can keep logging the user in even if they rotate the screen. This gets a little messy though because we could be trying to finish the activity while it's in no-man's land between an onDestroy and an onCreate. My guess is that since the phone you mentioned is older and slower, it takes much longer for the activity to recreate and attach itself to our fragments thus increasing the likelihood of a crash. Anyway, hopefully #618 will fix this kind of issue once and for all.

description: Crash when clicking on the help dialog button during login
fix:
Fixes #3511, the cause of the crash is that we are trying to access binding in setEnabled, but setEnabled is called from the base constructor, so binding is null there.
But when checking the code of super.setEnabled, I don't think we need to make any changes ourselves, as the base implementation updates the status for all child views:

description: App crashing when clicking on dropbox and Flickr from the accounts section.
fix: Changes: App crashing fixed for Dropbox authentication(App was crashing on aborting the authentication process after having initialized it). For Flickr, on aborting the authentication process midway, the authentication status was still being changed to successful(this should happen only in the case of successful authentication).

description: Unable to Open the Privacy Policy on the app's login page. This can become a hurdle in getting the app Reviewed in Release as Play Store Guidelines require there to be an accessible privacy policy, this can lead to app update getting rejected too.
